narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Question 14: I would have liked more reading material focused on conservation issues or perhaps even a separate course that focuses on conservation - the material focused on this topic seemed lacking.

The readings for this course were very helpful although quite dense and often too much. I think two readings per week would have been more manageable than three. The lectures were quite unhelpful to me. Professor Carpenter read her lecture notes straight from a paper, and read them so fast it was impossible for me to take coherent notes. It was also hard for me to learn because I was so focused on writing notes on what she said. It would have been really helpful if she had had something to reference after each lecture like a copy of her lecture notes or a summary of them, or a powerpoint or something. At the end of the course I tried to borrow notes from other classmates and their notes were as fragmented and often incomprehensible as mine. Professor Carpenter also tended to go off topic a lot, which was distracting and made following the actual class material difficult at times.
A good course; a little theory-heavy and at times obscure but worthwhile overall.
Professor Carpenter did an excellent job preparing the course and designing a comprehensive curriculum.

Question 10Lectures and readings, along with class discussions as well as clearly enriched by the instructor have provided a deep understanding of the course topics to students. This combination has prepared students to write the required final paper thesis that students have submitted at the end of the course completion.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Class discussion was a very valuable and well-emphasized component of the course
Readings, comparative analyses, final paper

The best aspects of this course were the discussions - some of them - with classmates about the topics we were examining. I also got a lot out of meeting with Matthew outside of class. He was very patient and good at explaining things.
The in-class discussions were very helpful for thinking about applications of the reading material. The final paper was also helpful for this.
Group discussions
Provoked students to think more about the broader context of conservation and development projects; why they're being done, who's benefitting, who's not, etc.
It covers a broad spectrum of social science perspectives on development work.
The readings prepared a solid foundation for class discussion and an excellent starting off point for further research.

The readings were really great and really invaluable for my interests. I really enjoyed them and the thesis sentences were really useful to refer to while writing the final paper. I loved the flexibility of the final paper and Carol was useful in helping me find a framing that was useful to explore my own research.
Writing a final paper thesis on a topic dealing with both environmental and social aspects, and class discussions on comparative analyses led by students were the best aspects of this course.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I felt like I would have liked lectures that reached beyond the scope of weekly readings, and less about the authors more about the topics at hand
More conservation articles and topics

As I mentioned above, the lectures that Professor Carpenter gave were quite challenging to follow. Her lecture style of just reading off a piece of paper was not very engaging and she read so fast it was hard to keep up / absorb everything she said. I felt the pace of the course was just too fast for someone without abackground in social sciences and thinkers like Foucault. I also felt that the thesis statement exercises were not very helpful - as I often felt that summarizing each reading into one sentence was too difficult. Is there another way to make sure people understand the readings? I don't know but I would consider other options.

I would like to see the paper requirement restructured a bit to motivate gradual progress throughout the semester. While I felt my knowledge and analytical skills gradually progressed, having to apply all of it at once to one topic was challenging. I could easily see all the authors' ideas in various parts of my chosen project for my final paper, but the challenge was in assessing what my strongest argument might be. This request could be facilitated by requiring an additional statement about the projects, sometime between the October and November breaks.
The pace of the class seemed a little slow.The readings selected seemed a little advanced for an introductory class.
Would have liked more discussion of how concepts can be applied practically, not just discussed theoretically.
Class discussions could have used more focus and spent more time with the authors' arguments.
The class lectures were pretty good, but could sometimes be a bit dry.While it was useful getting a primer on Foucault's ideas, sometimes it would have been nice to branch out from him a bit more.
The aspect of this course that needs Improvement is the use of the course website. Sometimes students were confused with the right space to post comparative analyses and the thesis sentences.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: na
NA
Would be excellent to encourage student discussion leaders to examine the text more closely.
Discussion got better over the course of the semester, but sometimes not be that useful in discussing the themes of the readings further.

The relationship between the course lectures and the class discussions was excellent! Students were trained to lead class discussions related to class readings and lectures, which provided students with a deep understanding of the course topics and modules.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: I thought the TF was really great and provided great context for the course. He was really straight-forward about his input and gave great suggestions for further readings and had good points about how the class readings and ideas linked to ongoing academic discussions. Really enjoyed his lecture.

The strengthens of the teaching assistant included a strong knowledge of the course topics and the good will to share this knowledge with the students. The weakness was that the teaching assistant responds to studentsâ emails rarely.

Instructor: Matthew Baird Archer  TA seemed to be readily available, but I felt that often there was a disconnect between him and the instructor. Would have also preferred more timely feedback on assignments and posting of weekly forums.

Instructor: Matthew Baird Archer  Matthew was good. Both he and Professor Carpenter seemed to have fairly limited office hours, which was challenging at times. I think that because Matthew seemed to have a good understanding of the themes discussed in the course, it might have been nice to have him translate some of Professor Carpenter's lectures in class since she was so hard to follow. That would have made the course a lot better - although it's not his fault that was needed.

Instructor: Matthew Baird Archer  The TA made himself very available and accessible to students. Would have liked more of his perspective on the material and concepts we were discussing, maybe more help in clarifying them.
Instructor: Matthew Baird Archer  Very helpful, friendly and accessible. Would have been interesting if he had taken an active role in discussion.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Fulfills a degree program requirement, also links to interests in social sciences within my degree. I've had social science coursework previously but this course supplemented it.

This course is less relevant to what I am studying now at Yale and more relevant to the work that I will be doing when I graduate (international conservation& development work). It was important to think about these programs critically and to question their effectiveness and whether they are necessary at all or doing what they aim to be doing. These themes taught in the course were very interesting and have certainly given me the vocabulary to critically assess programs which I plan to work with in the future.
The course has enabled me think about development programs, their design and implementation in a different way.

As someone interested in anthropological ideas and social issues around conservation and development, the course readings were a great base for me to have moving forward, and a great positioning in the ideas being discussed currently in the sector.

This course fitted well into my academic and professional programs. Coming from a conservation and sustainable development professional background, this course provided me with a fundamental understanding of conservation and development dynamics of partners and stakeholders at local, national and international levels, deepening all aspects involved in implementing sustainable development and conservation projects by analyzing case studies related to this field throughout different periods and spaces. In addition, this course has prepared me to analyze and suggest clear questions and topics for my research project involving indigenous an local communities with protected and non-protected areas in central Africa.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: See Question 20
I am conducting social science research and am interested in conservation science and though the readings would be helpful in offering me a different perspective.
I knew the themes taught in this course would be very relevant to my future career. I also had heard good things from other students about the course.
I used this course to reflect on my summer research project.
Relevant to my fields of interest
Wanted to flesh out my social perspective on conservation.
To gain an overview of how the social sciences perceive environmental challenges and development programs
For an introduction into anthropology and qualitative perspectives.
The topics were very relevant to my own research.

One of the reasons I took this course was to improve my abilities to read, understand and analyze scientific papers in the field of conservation and sustainable development. Also, I wanted to discuss different models and approaches in conservation and international development as well as their implications and avenues to contribute to a sustainable conservation of biodiversity at local and global scales.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
yes

Yes and no. I do feel that I learned a lot about certain themes and particularly the vocabulary from this course, however I felt that the topics covered were very cursory, and I would have liked to discuss a few more of the topics in further depth. No the course did not meet my expectations in a sense that I felt that I did not learn very much from the assignments. I mostly got what I got out of the course from my discussions with other students both in and outside of class, as well as by doing the readings.
Yes, though the literature was repetitive at times (e.g. Tanya Li). A piece by Scott and perhaps some new pieces on development (e.g. human rights) would provide more breadth.
Feel somewhat lacking given the amount of material covered.
I didn't have a lot of expectations, more of an introductory foray.
Yes
Great overview.
Overall, it did meet my expectations and I am glad I took it.
Yes, my expectations in this course were successfully met.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Group discussion was some of the more valuable components of this course, and requirements were in a good quantity (2x per term made this not too much to become a burden)

Advantages - outside discussion of reading material with my peers. Enjoyed meeting as a group with the TF and got the most out of the group work in that setting.Disadvantages - very easy for bulk of work (coming up with discussion questions) to fall on one member of the group.
NA
N/A
Helpful as a discussion aid.
It was fun to discuss the readings more in-depth with classmates and especially with the TF.
The group work enabled students to discuss and deepen their understanding in the course topics before class discussions.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Focus of the course is primarily development (or it seemed that way to me)

Take notes in a format that allow you to take notes as quickly as possible. I tried to write notes in the beginning but ended up typing them because I can type much faster than I can write. Perhaps set up meetings after class each week to go over themes discussed to make sure you understand them (either with the TF or with fellow classmates that have their stuff together).
Though 3 assignments are due every week, you should try to read 1-2 additional each week in preparation for your final project.
More appropriate for those with no background in anthropology.
Worthwhile course for students interested in anthropology and definitely valuable for those considering working for community/global development organizations or NGO's
Have an open mind
Great course - definitely take this your first semester as it provides a broad foundation for later understanding.
If the topic interests you, it is definitely worth your time, and Carol is really available and eager to help her students if you want to connect the course topics with other work you are doing.
I will strongly encourage them to take the course.
